== Summary ==
== Summary ==
â
As of 3 July 2008, 27 variations of Belgian commemorative coins have been minted: two in 2002, two in 2003, four in 2004, four in 2005, six in 2006, six in 2007, seven in 2008 and two in 2009 so far. These special high-value commemorative coins are not to be confused with [[â¬2 commemorative coins]], which are coins designated for circulation and do have legal tender status in all countries of the Eurozone.<ref>{{cite web | publisher=[[European Commission]] | url=http://ec.europa.eu/economy_finance/the_euro/notes_coins8787_en.htm | title=Different types of euro coins | accessdate=2008-06-24}}</ref>

| colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"|The [[euro]] was introduced in the [[Eurozone]] on 1 January 2002. As a result, Belgium started to mint collectors' coins in late 2002. This coin was their first euro [[commemorative coin]] released.
The [[Obverse and reverse|obverse]] (front side) shows a train coming out of one of the tunnels in the [[North-South connection]] in [[Brussels]]. It has written on the coin the words ''Noord-Zuidverbinding Jonction Nord-Midi'' (North-South connection in Dutch and French, respectively) and the years 1952 (representing the opening of the connection) and 2002.

| colspan="5" align=left | Although his well-known protagonist, [[Jules Maigret|Detective Inspector Maigret]], was [[Paris]]ian, [[Georges Simenon]] was one of most famous [[List of Belgians#Authors|Belgian writers]] of the 20th century. With more than 200 novels, most of them translated into several dozen languages and more than fifty adapted for television and the large screen, he has left a large collection of masterpieces behind. Two of them, ''My Friend Maigret'' (1949) and ''Maigret in Court'' (1960) were named in 1987 as two of the hundred best crime novels. For his work particularly on police novels, Belgium has chosen to honor the centennial of his birth (13 February 1903) with a 10-euro sterling silver commemorative coin.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.coin-currency.com/belgian.html | publisher=The coin and currency institute of Belgium | accessdate=2008-06-24 | title=100th Anniversary of Georges Simenon commemorative coin |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080417054627/http://www.coin-currency.com/belgian.html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2008-04-17}}</ref> The [[Obverse and reverse|obverse]] front side shows his portrait.
+

| colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"| The female character [[Europa (mythology)|Europa]], abducted by Zeus, watching the continent from the skies, is shown on the obverse of the coin.
The continent [[Europe]] has ultimately been named after this female character. In the eighth century, ecclesiastical uses of ''Europa'' for the imperium of [[Charlemagne]] provide the source for the modern geographical term. The name of Europe as a geographical term came in use by [[Ancient Greece|Ancient Greek]] geographers such as [[Strabo]].<ref>Strabo, Geography [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/cgi-bin/ptext?doc=Perseus:text:1999.01.0197:book=8:chapter=1:section=1 8.1.1]</ref> It is derived from the [[Greek language|Greek]] word ''Europa'' (ÎÏÏÏÏÎ·) in almost all European languages. Europa has been used frequently as a [[European symbols#Europa|symbol of Europe]]; statues of her and the bull, are placed outside several European Union institutions.

The stadium, also known as ''King Baudouin Stadium'' (French: ''Stade Roi Baudouin'', Dutch: ''Koning Boudewijnstadion''), is a sports ground in north-west [[Brussels]]. It was inaugurated on 23 August 1930 (days after Belgium's 100th anniversary) as the ''Stade du JubilÃ©'' or ''Jubelstadion'' ("Jubilee Stadium") in the presence of [[Leopold III of Belgium|Prince Leopold III]]. It was built to embellish the ''Heysel plateau'' in view of the 1935 [[World's Fair]]. The stadium hosted 70,000 people at the time. This coin was minted to celebrate the 75th anniversary of this event.

| colspan="5" align=left | The [[Belgian Revolution]] was a conflict in the [[United Kingdom of the Netherlands]] that began with a riot in [[Brussels]] in August 1830 and eventually led to the establishment of an independent, [[Roman Catholic]] and neutral Belgium ([[William I of the Netherlands|William I]], king of the Netherlands, would refuse to recognize a Belgian state until 1839, when he had to yield under pressure by the [[Treaty of London, 1839|Treaty of London]]). | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"| The [[Belgian Revolution]] was a conflict in the [[United Kingdom of the Netherlands]] that began with a riot in [[Brussels]] in August 1830 and eventually led to the establishment of an independent, [[Roman Catholic]] and neutral Belgium ([[William I of the Netherlands|William I]], king of the Netherlands, would refuse to recognize a Belgian state until 1839, when he had to yield under pressure by the [[Treaty of London, 1839|Treaty of London]]). This coin commemorates the 175th anniversary of this event.
The obverse depicts the famous painting "Scene of the September days in 1830",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dhm.de/ausstellungen/mythen/b25.html|title=Painting "Scene of the September days in 1830" | accessdate=2008-06-24 | publisher=[[Deutsches Historisches Museum]]}}</ref> a representation of the [[Belgian Revolution]]. On the reverse there is an effigy of King Albert II, facing to the left surrounded by the 12 stars of the European union. "Belgium" in the three official languages is displayed as well as the nominal value of 100 euro.

| colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"| The 400th anniversary of the death of Belgian philosopher [[Justus Lipsius]] is the theme of Belgium's contribution to the [[Europa Coins 2006|2006 Europa coin program]] of famous European personalities.
Born in 1547, Lipsius came to be known for his writings on stoicism. The most famous of these was entitled ''De Constantia'' ("On Constancy"), and in it he spoke of the merits of a Stoic-inspired ideal of constancy whenever people were faced with unpleasant events or circumstances. His teachings led to a philosophical movement known today as "[[Neostoicism]]". Lipsius died in 1606.<ref name=ECI_JL>{{cite web | url=http://www.eurocollections.com/catalog/?product=2086 | title=Belgium 2006 10â¬ Justus Lipsivs silver proof | publisher=Euro Collections International | accessdate=2008-06-24 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>

His teachings led to a philosophical movement known today as "[[Neostoicism]]". | colspan="5" align=left | This coin was minted as a tribute to an accident that occurred in the mines of ''Bois du Cazier'' at [[Marcinelle]].
+
| colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"| This coin was minted as a tribute to an accident that occurred in the mines of ''Bois du Cazier'' at [[Marcinelle]].
â
On the morning of 8 August 1956, a fire in the mines of Marcinelle caused 262 victims. At the time of the incident, 274 people were working in the colliery ''Bois du Cazier'', also known as ''Puits Saint-Charles''.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.emporis.com/en/wm/cx/?id=114223 | title=Description of the mine ''Bois du Cazier'' | accessdate=2008-06-24 | publisher=Emporis.com}}</ref> A wrongly placed mining wagon on the elevator cage hit an oil pipe and indirectly the electricity lines when the elevator started moving. This caused a fire, which trapped the miners working in the galleries. Only 12 people survived.
+
On the morning of 8 August 1956, a fire in the mines of Marcinelle caused 262 victims. At the time of the incident, 274 people were working in the colliery ''Bois du Cazier'', also known as ''Puits Saint-Charles''.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.emporis.com/en/wm/cx/?id=114223 | title=Description of the mine ''Bois du Cazier'' | accessdate=2008-06-24 | publisher=Emporis.com}}</ref> A wrongly placed mining wagon on the elevator cage hit an oil pipe and indirectly the electricity lines when the elevator started moving. This caused a fire, which trapped the miners working in the galleries. Only 12 people survived.
The obverse shows a portrait of a miner, with the mine ''Bois du Cazier'' in the background. In one version of the coin, the portrait of the miner is minted in copper, which gives a unique character to this coin.

+
| colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"| This was the first 12.50-euro coin ever minted by Belgium. The obverse of the coin shows a portrait of [[Leopold I of Belgium|Leopold I]], the father of the [[Monarchy of Belgium|Belgian dynasty]].
On the reverse, a seated lion can be observed. The design of this lion is an original resemblance of a very old coin: the 2 centimes made of copper, minted from 1835 to 1865, one of the very first coins minted by the Belgian dynasty.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.treasurerealm.com/coinpapers/countrycoins/B/Belgium.html | title=Historical Belgian Coins | publisher = Treasure Realm | accessdate=2008-06-24 }}</ref> Under the lion, the words "Belgium" in the three official languages and the face value of 12.50 euro can be seen.
On the reverse, a seated lion can be observed. The design of this lion is an original resemblance of a very old coin: the 2 centimes made of copper, minted from 1835 to 1865, one of the very first coins minted by the Belgian dynasty.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.treasurerealm.com/coinpapers/countrycoins/B/Belgium.html | title=Historical Belgian Coins | publisher = Treasure Realm | accessdate=2008-06-24 }}</ref> Under the lion, the words "Belgium" in the three official languages and the face value of 12.50 euro can be seen.

| colspan="5" align=left | This coin was issued to commemorate the 100th anniversary of [[Maurice Maeterlinck]]'s greatest contemporary success: ''[[The Blue Bird (play)|L'Oiseau Bleu]]'', written in 1908. | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"| This coin was issued to commemorate the 100th anniversary of [[Maurice Maeterlinck]]'s greatest contemporary success: ''[[The Blue Bird (play)|L'Oiseau Bleu]]'', written in 1908. Maurice was a Belgian poet, playwright, and essayist writing in French. He was awarded the [[Nobel Prize in Literature]] in 1911.
The play premiered on 30 September 1908 at Constantin Stanislavski's Moscow Art Theatre and has been turned into several films and a TV series. The story is about a girl called Mytyl and her brother Tyltyl seeking happiness, represented by The Blue Bird of Happiness, aided by the good fairy Berylune.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.electacollections.com/ViewShopProduct.aspx?Id=257468&langid=2&Name=Belgium+-+50+Euro+gold+Proof%2c+L+Oiseau+bleu%2c+Maurice+Maeterlinck%2c+2008 | title=Belgium - 50 euro gold Proof, L Oiseau bleu, Maurice Maeterlinck Commemorative Coin | publisher=The Eurocoins Store | accessdate=2008-06-24 }}</ref>

| colspan="5" align=left | On the occasion of the [[2008 Summer Olympics]] in Beijing, China, the Royal Mint of Belgium have issued a commemorative coin in silver. The reverse shows on the right side a nominal value of 10 euro and the year of issue (2008), and in the center a map of Europe with all 27 member states of the EU.
+
| colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"| On the occasion of the [[2008 Summer Olympics]] in Beijing, China, the Royal Mint of Belgium have issued a commemorative coin in silver. The reverse shows on the right side a nominal value of 10 euro and the year of issue (2008), and in the center a map of Europe with all 27 member states of the EU.
The obverse carries on the right side a symbol of the Belgian [[International Olympic Committee|Olympic Committee]], in the center an analog of the ''Olympic flambeau'', which will constantly burn during the [[Olympic Games]], and on the left side symbols of four [[Olympic sports|Olympic disciplines]]: [[Cycling at the Summer Olympics|cycling]], [[Field hockey at the Summer Olympics|hockey]], [[Athletics at the Summer Olympics|athletics]] and [[Tennis at the Summer Olympics|tennis]].
The obverse carries on the right side a symbol of the Belgian [[International Olympic Committee|Olympic Committee]], in the center an analog of the ''Olympic flambeau'', which will constantly burn during the [[Olympic Games]], and on the left side symbols of four [[Olympic sports|Olympic disciplines]]: [[Cycling at the Summer Olympics|cycling]], [[Field hockey at the Summer Olympics|hockey]], [[Athletics at the Summer Olympics|athletics]] and [[Tennis at the Summer Olympics|tennis]].

| colspan="5" align=left | The International Expo in Belgium, also known as ''[[Expo 58]]'' or ''Brussels Worldâs Fair'', was held from 17 April to 19 October 1958. It was the first major [[World's Fair]] after [[World War II]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://flanderstoday.eu/jahia/Jahia/pid/1586 | title=When the world was in Brussels | publisher=Flanders Today | date=2008-11-29}}</ref>
+
| colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"| The International Expo in Belgium, also known as ''[[Expo 58]]'' or ''Brussels Worldâs Fair'', was held from 17 April to 19 October 1958. It was the first major [[World's Fair]] after [[World War II]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://flanderstoday.eu/jahia/Jahia/pid/1586 | title=When the world was in Brussels | publisher=Flanders Today | date=2008-11-29}} {{dead link|date=June 2011}}</ref>
The site is best known for a giant model of a unit cell of an iron crystal (each sphere representing an [[atom]]), called the [[Atomium]], which decades later remains one of the best known landmarks of Brussels. More than 42 million visitors visited the site, which was opened with a call for world peace and social and economic progress, issued by [[Baudouin of Belgium|King Baudouin I]].
The site is best known for a giant model of a unit cell of an iron crystal (each sphere representing an [[atom]]), called the [[Atomium]], which decades later remains one of the best known landmarks of Brussels. This coin was issued to celebrate the 50th anniversary of this event; on the obverse of the coin the logo of the exposition is depicted.

| colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"| [[Desiderius Erasmus|Desiderius Erasmus Roterodamus]] (sometimes known as ''Desiderius Erasmus of Rotterdam'') was a [[Netherlands|Dutch]] [[Renaissance humanist]] and [[Roman Catholic Church|Catholic]] [[Christian]] [[theology|theologian]]. Erasmus was a classical scholar who wrote in a "pure" [[Latin language|Latin]] style and enjoyed the [[sobriquet]] "Prince of the Humanists." <ref>Latourette, Kenneth Scott. A History of Christianity. New York: Harper & Brothers, 1953, p. 661.</ref>
One of his masterpieces is the essay [[The Praise of Folly]] ([[Greek language|Greek]] title: ''Morias Enkomion (ÎÏÏÎ¯Î±Ï ÎÎ³ÎºÏÎ¼Î¹Î¿Î½)'', [[Latin]]: ''Stultitiae Laus'', sometimes translated as "In Praise of Folly", [[Dutch language|Dutch]] title: ''Lof der Zotheid''); written in 1509. Erasmus revised and extended the work while sojourning with Sir [[Thomas More]]. ''In Praise of Folly'' is considered one of the most influential works of literature in Western civilization and one of the catalysts of the [[Protestant Reformation]].
One of his masterpieces is the essay [[The Praise of Folly]] ([[Greek language|Greek]] title: ''Morias Enkomion (ÎÏÏÎ¯Î±Ï ÎÎ³ÎºÏÎ¼Î¹Î¿Î½)'', [[Latin]]: ''Stultitiae Laus'', sometimes translated as "In Praise of Folly", [[Dutch language|Dutch]] title: ''Lof der Zotheid''); written in 1509. Erasmus revised and extended the work while sojourning with Sir [[Thomas More]]. ''In Praise of Folly'' is considered one of the most influential works of literature in Western civilization and one of the catalysts of the [[Protestant Reformation]].
The 500th Anniversary of this essay is the main motif for the firsts two commemorative coins in 2009. On the [[Obverse and reverse|obverse]] of the coin, is an [[effigy]] of Erasmus. To his left are two samples of the most famous pen and ink illustrations from the 1515 edition.<ref>Wolf, 2004, p. 11</ref> In the center of the coin, the years MDIX (1509 in [[roman numerals]]) and 2009 are clearly shown. The [[Obverse and reverse|reverse]] shows a view of all the countries of the Eurozone, surrounded by the word "Belgium" in its three official languages and the face value of 10 euro.
